items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
The forecast is mainly dry for the first half of next week, however a wetter period is forecast as we move towards the weekend. The ground is still very wet and so rivers will respond more quickly to any rainfall.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are falling on the River Thame upstream of Stadhampton where levels are rising slowly as water moves downstream. River levels are still high but falling in the Thame area where flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
The weather forecast is for a dry start with the chance of showers this evening. Tuesday is forecast to be dry. River levels still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 25/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. There is no forecast flood risk from high tides over the next few days. The weather forecast is mostly dry for today and tomorrow, with some patchy rain expected this afternoon and evening.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire
